Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{wp|lang=ja}} {{wp|Hakama}} [[File:Mikohakamaback.JPG|thumb|250px|''{{ja-l||袴}}'' (''hakama'', traditional Japanese trousers)]]
{{ja-kanjitab|はかま|yomi=k}} From {{inh|ja|ojp|sort=はかま|-}}. Attested in the ''{{w|Man'yōshū}}'', completed some time after 759 {{CE}}. Appears to be a compound deriving ultimately from {{compound|ja|sort=はかま||alt1=穿か|tr1=haka|pos1=the {{m|ja|未然形|tr=mizenkei||incomplete form}} or a sound shift from some other conjugation of verb {{m|ja|穿く|tr=haku||to pull onto the lower body (such as trousers)}}|裳|tr2=ma|t2=robes|pos2=sound shift from expected reading ''mo''}}.{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}} The {{m|en|loincloth}} sense is attested earlier in the ''{{w|Nihon Shoki}}'', finished in 720 {{CE}}.{{R:Daijirin}} Other sources{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}} also cite the ''Nihon Shoki'' for the {{m|en|trousers}} sense, possibly suggesting confusion regarding the meaning of the term as used in that text.
